title: Traumatic Tympanic Membrane Perforation
chief_complaint: I fell out of a deer stand a few weeks ago and a branch punctured my left eardrum. Since then, I've had pain, ringing, and trouble hearing in that ear.

problem_summary.onset: Acute onset a few weeks prior following a traumatic fall.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Tinnitus, otalgia (ear pain), and trauma to the bridge of the nose.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Difficulty hearing from the left side.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Evaluation of hearing status following trauma.

history.present_illness: Patient fell 20 feet from a deer stand a few weeks ago, landing on his left side. A branch punctured his left tympanic membrane and the bridge of his nose.
history.otologic_history: Reports otalgia and tinnitus in the left ear since the fall. Right ear is normal.
history.medical_psych_history: Trauma to nose bridge during the same fall.
history.prior_management: None specified prior to this evaluation.
history.patient_goals: Assess hearing loss and ear status.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear shows normal hearing sensitivity. Left ear shows a flat mild-to-moderate conductive hearing loss with a significant air-bone gap.

numeric_results.Left_Air_Conduction: Flat configuration approx 30-40 dB HL across 250-8000 Hz

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Excellent word recognition scores bilaterally. SRTs are in agreement with PTAs.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear is normal (Type A). Left ear is flat (Type B) with an abnormally large ear canal volume, consistent with tympanic membrane perforation.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Right ipsilateral reflexes present. All other conditions (Left Ipsi, Right Contra, Left Contra) are absent due to the conductive pathology in the left ear.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with normal hearing in the right ear and a mild-to-moderate flat conductive hearing loss in the left ear. Word recognition is excellent bilaterally. Immittance testing confirms a large tympanic membrane perforation in the left ear (Type B tympanogram with large volume), consistent with the reported trauma.
counseling_points: Your hearing test confirms a conductive hearing loss in your left ear, meaning sound is being blocked from reaching the inner ear.
The 'flat' line on the pressure test (tympanogram) combined with a large volume measurement confirms there is a hole (perforation) in your eardrum.
The good news is that your inner ear nerve function is completely normal, as shown by your bone conduction scores and 100% word recognition.
You should keep the ear dry and avoid water entry to prevent infection.
We will refer you to an ENT specialist to discuss surgical repair (tympanoplasty) of the perforation.
notes_for_actor: Portray a patient who is generally healthy but concerned about the recent accident.
You may mention pain or discomfort in the left ear.
You are aware of the cause (the branch puncture) but want to know if the hearing loss is permanent.
